23 September 2009 |prevseason=[[2008â09 Manchester City F.C. season|2008â09]] |nextseason=[[2010â11 Manchester City F.C. season|2010â11]] }} The [[2009â10 in English football|'''2009â10 season''']] is [[Manchester City F.C.|'''Manchester City Football Club''']]'s eighth consecutive season playing in the [[Premier League]], the top division of [[Football in England|English football]], and its thirteenth season since the Premier League was first created with Manchester City as one of the its original 22 founding member clubs. Overall, it is the team's 118th season playing in a division of English football, most of which have been spent in the top flight. The club started the season under the management of [[Mark Hughes]] who was controversially sacked in mid-December after the team notched up seven consecutive draws in the Premier League. {{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/m/man_city/8422676.stm | title=Mark Hughes sacked as Man City appoint Mancini manager | date=2009-12-19 | accessdate=2010-11-21 | work=BBC Sport | publisher=British Broadcasting Corporation }} He was replaced by the Italian manager [[Roberto Mancini]]. ==Season review== After only five months in the job at [[City of Manchester Stadium|Eastlands]], new manager Roberto Mancini demonstrated that he clearly deserved, and should get, more time to "mould the team to his own image." {{cite news | url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/sport/football/3158611/Roberto-Mancini-Judge-Man-City-in-six-months-time.html | title=Mancini: I need more time | date=2010-09-29 | accessdate=2011-02-20 | work=thesun.co.uk | publisher=News Group Newspapers Ltd. | location=London }} In his first few months in the job, after succeeding Mark Hughes in December, the Italian did make some noticeable improvements to the team, such as ironing out its occasional lack of focus and cohesion in defence whilst also improving the overall mentality of the team. Yet by the end of the season it had become obvious that there was much work still to be done in order to convince some of Mancini's higher-profile players to sign up to his personal [[ethos]]. {{cite news | url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1314670/Roberto-Mancini-Interview-I-came-Manchester-City-win--weather.html | title=Roberto Mancini interview: I came to Manchester City to win - not for the weather! | date=2010-09-24 | accessdate=2011-02-20 | work=dailymail.co.uk | publisher=Associated Newspapers Ltd. | location=London | first=Martin | last=Samuel }} With a prolific 29 goals in his first season at the club, [[Carlos TÃ©vez]] was widely regarded as the club's best and most important player this season, {{cite web | url=http://www.themanchesterunited.com/article.asp?articleid=103816&Manchester-City-v-Manchester-United-Carlos-Tvez-has-made-Gary-Neville-eat-his-words | title=Carlos TÃ©vez has made Gary Neville eat his words | date=2010-11-10 | accessdate=2011-02-20 | work=themanchesterunited.com | publisher=(Creative Commons BY-NC-ND 3.0) }} with the feisty Argentinian striker becoming an almost talismanic figurehead, not just for the team on the field of play and the fans in the stands, but also with regard to the whole ''zeitgeist'' associated with this new era in the club's history. Unfortunately for City, this campaign saw too many of his team mates failing to match his high work rate and fecund output. {{cite news | url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/manchester-city/6975729/Carlos-Tevez-proves-his-value-to-Manchester-City-with-hat-trick.html | title=Carlos TÃ©vez proves his value to Manchester City with hat-trick | date=2010-01-13 | accessdate=2011-02-20 | work=telegraph.co.uk | publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited | location=London | first=Mark | last=Ogden }} There were a number of players who flattered to deceive this season, with the most notable of them being the previous season's fan's favourite and top scorer, [[RÃ³bson de Souza|Robinho]]. The Brazilian's second season in English football proved to be a disastrous one for both the "marquee signing" and the Mark who signed him, with his January loan out to Brazilian club [[Santos FC|Santos]] for the remainder of the season {{cite news | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2010/jan/28/robinho-manchester-city-santos-loan | title=Robinho leaves Manchester City for Santos on six-month loan deal | date=2010-01-28 | accessdate=2010-11-26 | work=guardian.co.uk | publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited | location=London | first=Sachin | last=Nakrani }} only serving to emphasise the magnitude of his failure to deliver on the pitch anything remotely comparable to what he had already received in his bank account. The loss in the team's last home game of the season to fellow rivals for landing one of the Premier League's "Top Four" elite slots, [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]], in what had been dubbed by the media beforehand as the "[[UEFA Champions League|Champions League]] play-off" game, was considered by many observers to be the Manchester club's defining moment of the season. {{cite news | url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1274061/Peacelands-Roberto-Mancini-safe-Manchester-City-finally-talk-sense.html | title=Peacelands! Roberto Mancini is safe as Manchester City finally talk sense | date=2010-05-07 | accessdate=2011-02-21 | work=dailymail.co.uk | publisher=Associated Newspapers Ltd. | location=London | first=Ian | last=Ladyman }} Breaking the established stranglehold of the "[[Big_Four_(English_football)#.22Big_Four.22_dominance|Big Four]]" had been, and still is, one of the ambitions of the club's new wealthy owners, yet the players they expensively accumulated to achieve this feat failed to deliver, if only marginally so. However, one of the positives for City to be taken from this season's campaign will be that the club reached its first major semi-final since 1981 (albeit with the most expensive squad ever assembled to try to win the [[Carling Cup]]) before finally succumbing to the eventual trophy winners and bitter rivals from across the city, [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]]. {{cite news | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2010/jan/19/carling-cup-manchester-city-manchester-united | title=Carlos Tevez surge leaves Manchester United reeling in Carling Cup | date=2010-01-19 | accessdate=2010-11-26 | work=guardian.co.uk | publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited | location=London | first=Kevin | last=McCarra }} {{cite news | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2010/jan/27/manchester-united-manchester-city-carling-cup | title=Wayne Rooney takes Manchester United past City into Carling Cup final | date=2010-01-27 | accessdate=2010-11-26 | work=guardian.co.uk | publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited | location=London | first=Kevin | last=McCarra }} The City team also notched up some highly noteworthy victories over the other "Top Four" incumbents, [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] {{cite news | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2009/dec/05/premier-league-manchester-city-chelsea | title=Emmanuel Adebayor atones as Chelsea pay the penalty | date=2009-12-05 | accessdate=2010-11-26 | work=guardian.co.uk | publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited | location=London | first=Joe | last=Lovejoy }} {{cite news | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2010/feb/27/chelsea-manchester-city-premier-league | title=Chelsea see red as Manchester City triumph in battle of the Bridge | date=2010-02-27 | accessdate=2010-11-26 | work=guardian.co.uk | publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited | location=London | first=Paul | last=Wilson }} and [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]]. {{cite news | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2009/sep/12/premier-league-manchester-city-arsenal | title=Emmanuel Adebayor is on target as City's late onslaught sinks Arsenal | date=2009-09-12 | accessdate=2010-11-26 | work=guardian.co.uk | publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited | location=London | first=Louise | last=Taylor }} {{cite news | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2009/dec/02/carling-cup-manchester-city-arsenal | title=Carlos Tevez hauls Manchester City's bandwagon back on the road | date=2010-12-03 | accessdate=2010-11-26 | work=guardian.co.uk | publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited | location=London | first=Kevin | last=McCarra }} In fact, Manchester City earned itself the distinction of being the only team to do the "[[Double (association football)|league double]]" over the team that ultimately achieved the "[[2009â10 Premier League|league]] and [[2009â10 FA Cup|cup]] [[Double (association football)|double]]" this season. So as much as the season may have seemed like yet another false dawn to the ever-faithful and loyal City fans, {{cite news | url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/manchester-city/7686534/Manchester-City-fans-suffer-another-false-dawn.html | title=Manchester City fans suffer another false dawn | date=2010-05-07 | accessdate=2010-11-26 | work=telegraph.co.uk | publisher=Telegraph Media Group Limited | location=London | first=Jim | last=White }} the club is in reality "a work in progress" {{cite news | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/blog/2009/aug/25/manchester-city-mark-hughes-premier-league-fear | title=Mark Hughes has work before Manchester City gain fear and loathing | date=2009-08-25 | accessdate=2010-11-26 | work=guardian.co.uk | publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited | location=London | first=Kevin | last=McCarra }} {{cite news | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2010/nov/23/manchester-city-vincent-kompany-silva | title=Manchester City growing stronger as a team insists Vincent Kompany | date=2010-11-23 | accessdate=2010-11-26 | work=guardian.co.uk | publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited | location=London }} that appears to still be on course to arrive where it ultimately wants to be, {{cite news | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2009/sep/18/manchester-city-abu-dhabi-mubarak | title=From desert skyscrapers to Manchester City's sky blue land of riches | date=2009-09-18 | accessdate=2011-02-20 | work=guardian.co.uk | publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited | location=London | first=David | last=Conn }} {{cite news | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2009/sep/19/inside-manchester-city-david-conn | title=How the takeover of Manchester City came just in time to rescue a club in disarray | date=2009-09-19 | accessdate=2011-02-20 | work=guardian.co.uk | publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited | location=London | first=David | last=Conn }} {{cite news | url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/football/2009/sep/20/inside-manchester-city-takeover | title=The big-money deals are done, now for a place in the Premier League top four | date=2009-09-20 | accessdate=2011-02-20 | work=guardian.co.uk | publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited | location=London | first=David | last=Conn }} and with more new signings in the close season, will presumably get even closer to achieving its very ambitious agenda next season. Given that the club is building its team from a much weaker base than Chelsea did under [[Roman Abramovich]] (viz. Chelsea had already finished fourth in the Premier League in the [[2002â03 FA Premier League|2002â03 season]] before Abramovich purchased the club in June 2003) progress will naturally be somewhat slower despite the vast wealth of City's current ownership. So this season's campaign should still be considered to be a successful one for City, regardless of the fact that the team narrowly missed its main goal of qualifying for an opportunity to play in the [[2010â11 UEFA Champions League|Champions League in 2010â11]].

==Team kit== For this season the shirt sponsor for all of the club's kits was [[Etihad Airways]] which replaced the previous season's sponsor, [[Thomas Cook Group|Thomas Cook]]. There was also a change in the supplier of those kits for this season, with [[Nike, Inc.|Nike]] owned [[Umbro]] replacing the previous season's supplier, [[Le Coq Sportif]]. As a result of the switch from its prior French kit supplier to the Greater Manchester-based Umbro, all of the club's previous season's team and goalkeeper kits were essentially replaced with new ones for this season. The overall sky blue color of the first team kit was retained but the style and trim if this strip was significantly changed. Completely new away and third team kits were introduced, while a new all green goalkeeper strip replaced the previous season's gold and black strip as the primary one for use by the stoppers, with a newly styled and trimmed variant of the old gold and black strip now becoming the secondary strip for use by the keepers in away fixtures. The new all black away team kit came with gold vertical shoulder trim on the front that enabled the kit to be color coordinated with the gold and black goalkeeper strip, although it was sometimes also used with the all green goalkeeper strip. This gold and black color scheme was, according to its designer David Blanch, {{cite web | url=http://blog.umbro.com/2009/07/30/mcfc-away-kit-available-to-pre-order/ | title=MCFC Away Kit available to pre-order | date=2009-07-30 | accessdate=2010-11-17 | work=umbro.com | publisher=(Umbro) }} intended to be symbolic of the globe covered with bees (representing the world, to all parts of which the goods of the city are exported) that is featured on the city of [http://www.ngw.nl/int/gbr/m/images/manchest.jpg Manchester coat of arms]. That is because the Manchester City teams in the past have established the unique tradition of always wearing this [http://shop.mcfc.co.uk/stores/product_images/mcfc-39678.jpg?width=400&height=400&quality=95 crest on their shirts] when playing at Wembley (or in a major cup final elsewhere) as a symbol of their pride in representing the city of Manchester at a major sporting event. In heraldic terms, the bee is symbolic of a hive of industry, and even today the Manchester bee is often used all by itself as a shorthand emblem for the city of Manchester. The red and black diagonal sash across the white shirts of the new third team kit was intended as a nostalgic re-mastering of the original sashed strip worn by the City team back in the seventies, {{cite web | url=http://www.mcfc.co.uk/News/Club-news/2009/August/Back-to-the-future-for-third-kit | title=Back to the future for third kit | date=2009-08-28 | accessdate=2010-11-04 | work=mcfc.co.uk | publisher=(Manchester City Football Club) }} while that original design had, in its turn, been a nod back at the classic red and black striped shirts with black shorts that had originally been introduced by coach [[Malcolm Allison]] in imitation of [[A.C. Milan]]'s strip, and which was frequently worn in its cup ties by the successful trophy-winning [http://www.radiotimes.com/content/features/galleries/football-covers/09/mainImage.jpg City team] of the late sixties and early seventies. {| border="0" |{{Football kit box | align = none center | pattern_la = | pattern_b = _whitecollar | pattern_ra = | pattern_sh = | pattern_so = _transparent tops on
